li.p: The logophoric interpretation of free anaphors

subsection.heading: 1 Background
subsection.p: According to the canonical Binding Theory (Chomsky 1981), nominal expressions occur in three basic types: (i) anaphors, (ii) pronominals, and (iii) R-expressions. Anaphors are characterized as expressions that have no inherent capacity for reference. Hence, they must depend on some other expression in the sentence for their interpretation (their antecedent). Pronominals may, but need not depend on another expression for their interpretation. They are characterized by the fact that their features are drawn solely from a set of grammatical features, phi-features (in many languages just gender, number, and person). R-expressions have some additional features (grammatical and/or lexical). 1 Certain anaphors are like pronominals in that they only consist of phi-features. Other anaphors are morphologically complex and may contain other features as well. Anaphors and pronominals are together often referred to as pronouns.

The linguistic encoding of interpretive dependencies between nominal expressions and their antecedents is governed by the Binding Theory. For anaphors, the Binding Theory stipulates that they must be bound in a local domain (Condition A of the Binding Theory). Within the class of anaphors a further distinction is made between reflexive and non-reflexive anaphors. Loosely speaking, reflexive anaphors have an argument of the same predicate as their antecedent, non-reflexive anaphors do not (for a more precise exposition, see chapter 9).

subsection.heading: 2 The notion of logophoricity
subsection.p: One of the challenges for the canonical Binding Theory, discussed by Clements (1975) among others, is the fact that the behavior of anaphors is not always clear-cut. Languages may have forms that must be bound in one environment, and need not be bound in another. 2 A typical example is sig in Icelandic. It must have a binder in (1a) (and failing this, due to a feature mismatch between þú and sig, it is ill-formed):

(1)
a. *þú hefur svikið sig.
you have betrayed self
b. María var alltaf svo andstyggileg. þegar Olafurj kaemi segði hún séri/*j áreiðanlega að fara. (Thráinsson 1991)
‘Mary was always so nasty. When Olaf would come, she would certainly tell himself [the person whose thoughts are being presented – not Olaf] to leave.’

In (1b) sér is without a linguistically expressed antecedent, and yet the sentence is well-formed. 3 Traditionally anaphors such as sig in (1b) were called indirect reflexives. Hagège illustrates the indirect reflexive with the Latin example in (2) (Hagège 1974: 289, my gloss and annotation):

(2)
(Patres conscripti) legatos . . . miserunt . . . qui a
senators delegates sent who from
rege peterent [ne inimicissimum suum secum haberet sibique dedere].
king asksubj that not biggest enemy refl2
refl1-with keepsubj
refl2-and givesubj
‘The senatorsi sent delegates to ask the kingj not to keep theiri biggest enemyk with himj and to give [himk] to themi.’ (Cornelius Nepos, 23, 12, 2).

Suum, se, and sibi are all formally anaphors (reflexives in Hagège 1974). 4 As he points out, (2) shows two quite different uses, however. One use (in secum) is properly reflexive (rendered as ‘refl1’ in the gloss), the other use is not, but rather refers to the author of the request (rendered as ‘refl2’ in the gloss). 5 It is impossible for sibi in (2) to refer to individuals different from the senators, as would be the case if it were replaced by the pronominal form eis.

This second use is special since the reflexive, although it is technically bound, is not bound in a local domain, contra to what Condition A would lead one to expect; rather the binding relation crosses two (subjunctive) clausal boundaries. Such a use of reflexive-like forms is not limited to Icelandic or Latin, but widespread over the languages of the world. 6

Since Clements, the term logophor has come to be used for such anaphors. The term logophor was earlier introduced by Hagège (1974) for a different purpose, namely, to characterize a class of pronouns in languages from the Niger-Congo family that refer to the ‘auteur d’un discours’ (the ‘source of a discourse’, in the terms of Clements 1975). As Hagège puts it: “These pronouns distinguish the individual to which they refer from the speaker himself who uses them, in . . . ‘indirect speech’” (Hagège 1974: 287, my translation). They refer to the individual cited, the secondary speaker, as opposed to the primary speaker.

Such a formally distinct series of pronouns for this type of use is found in, for instance, Mundang, Tuburi, and Ewe from the Niger-Congo family. These pronouns bear no formal resemblance to reflexives, hence Hagège considers the term ‘indirect reflexive’ inappropriate. It is for these, therefore, that Hagège introduces the term ‘logophoric’. 7 Yet, as Hagège and Clements noted, the discourse function of such logophoric pronouns is similar to the indirect reflexive (Hagège 1974; Clements 1975).
The parallel between indirect reflexives and logophors is illustrated by the following example from Ewe (Clements 1975):

(3)
Tsali gbl
na-e be ye-e dyi yè gake yè-kpe dyi.
Tsali say to-Pron that Pron beget LOG but LOG be victor
‘Tsalii told himj (i.e., his father) that hej begot himi but hei was the victor.’

Here LOG is the gloss for the logophoric pronoun yè. 8 Only Tsali, the source of the reported discourse, can be the antecedent of yè. As Clements notes, it is not necessary that the clause containing the logophoric pronoun be subjacent to the clause containing the antecedent. The logophoric pronoun may occur at any depth of embedding. In fact these pronouns do not require a cosentential antecedent – the antecedent can be several sentences back. The subsequent sentences of the discourse will continue to present the events described by the narrator from the point of view of the same individual or individuals (Clements 1975: 170).

The terminology of Hagège, and most of the standard typological literature with him, explicitly distinguishes indirect reflexives from logophoric pronouns. Modern syntactic literature often follows the usage of Clements (1975), which extends Hagège's. In this usage, logophoricity is what characterizes both the special forms of (3) and the non-local and/or free use of anaphors in Icelandic and Latin as in (1b) and (2) and in many other languages (varying from Chinese and Japanese, to Italian and English).
Clements gives the following cross-linguistic characterization of logophoric pronouns (Clements 1975: 171–2):

li.p: logophoric pronouns are restricted to reportive contexts transmitting the words or thoughts of an individual or individuals other than the speaker/narrator;
the antecedent does not occur in the same reportive context as the logophoric pronoun;
the antecedent designates the individual or individuals whose words or thoughts are transmitted in the reported context in which the logophoric pronoun occurs.

subsection.p: Clements observes that in some languages logophoric pronouns may occur in sentences that strictly speaking do not satisfy conditions (i–iii), but that are in some sense modeled on sentences in which these conditions are satisfied. He notes that these conditions are primarily semantic/pragmatic, but does not elaborate on this.

Clements argues that there are no universal syntactic conditions on logophoric pronouns, such as a strict subjecthood condition on the antecedent. Languages do, however, impose varying idiosyncratic conditions on logophors. In Ewe, for instance, logophors are restricted to clauses introduced by the complementizer be. 9,10 Icelandic logophoric anaphora requires a subjunctive, in Mandarin Chinese the antecedent must be a living human being, etc. 11

subsection.heading: 3 Long-distance anaphora
subsection.p: Much of the syntactic study of indirect reflexives, which will henceforth be referred to by the more neutral term free anaphors, has been conducted from the perspective of long-distance anaphora, and the questions they raise for the canonical Binding Theory. As noted in section 1, binding Condition A (Chomsky 1981) expresses that anaphors must be locally bound:

row.entry: An anaphor must be bound in its governing category.
&ggr; is a governing category for α if and only if &ggr; is the minimal category containing α, a governor of α, and a SUBJECT (accessible to α). 12

subsection.p: Anaphors exceptionally allowing an antecedent beyond their SUBJECT are classified as long-distance anaphors. Icelandic logophoric anaphora forms a paradigm case.
Three types of exceptions have been distinguished:

li.p: anaphors that are properly bound by an antecedent outside the governing category assigned under (4);
anaphors that are properly interpreted without a c-commanding antecedent;
anaphors that are properly interpreted without a linguistically expressed antecedent.

subsection.p: An influential line of research considered (i) as the canonical instance of such exceptions. Within this approach the possibility of non-local binding is captured by parameterizing the factors entering into the computation of the governing category (Manzini and Wexler 1987; see also Dalrymple 1993). Manzini and Wexler revise Condition A as in (5):

row.entry: An anaphor must be bound in its governing category.
&ggr; is a governing category for α if and only if &ggr; is the minimal category containing α, a governor of α, and F (an opacity factor).

subsection.p: F is taken to assume values such as (accessible) SUBJECT, Tense, Agr, or Comp. Particular anaphors may lexically differ in the value they select. Essential in this approach is that all processes interpreting anaphors are uniformly binding processes.

It has been established, however, that the nature of the relation between anaphors and their antecedents is not uniform across domains (Hellan 1988; Thráinsson 1990, 1991; Reuland and Sigurjónsdóttir 1997). Even languages allowing all three options given above do not necessarily allow them under the same conditions. Exceptions of types (ii) and (iii) are not only sensitive to syntactic factors and parameters (Everaert 1986b). They are also subject to specific non-structural conditions to be met by the discourse in which they are embedded. This is what will be focused on next (see also chapter 33).

subsection.heading: 4 Theoretical issues in logophoricity
subsection.p: Over the last decades logophoricity has received attention from a typological, a syntactic, and a semantic perspective. The first type of perspective is exemplified by work such as Hagège (1974), Hyman and Comrie (1981), Frajzyngier (1985), Wiesemann (1986), von Roncador (1992), Culy (1994, 1997). These works contain an array of important findings about the ways in which logophoricity is encoded cross-linguistically, some quite challenging for theory formation, for instance verbal markings of logophoricity (see, e.g., Curnow 2002). To some extent independent of the details of the typological findings, the semantics of attititudes, reports, perspective, indexicals, and self-representation has drawn the attention of linguists and philosophers. Some illustrative works are Lewis (1979), Chierchia (1989), Kaplan (1989), Reinhart (1991), and, more recently, Higginbotham (2003). In addition, there is a growing body of literature in which typological, syntactic and semantic considerations are brought together under a general perspective. Clements (1975) can be considered the first representative of this approach, followed by Sells (1987). These authors present a general perspective on both logophoric pronouns of the Niger-Congo type and logophoric anaphors. This line of research constitutes an attempt to explicitly incorporate the role of discourse factors in a general Binding Theory (formulated from the perspective of discourse representation theory; Kamp 1981b). 13

In recent years Tancredi (1997), Safir (2003), Schlenker (2003a), Sigurðsson (2004) presented intriguing endeavors toward an integrated approach based on their contributions toward a general theory of the interpretation of indexicals with respect to the context of utterance, and the accessibility of context in the interpretation of reports. Of crucial importance was the inclusion into the debate of languages like Amharic. In Amharic one finds shifted interpretations of first person pronouns in reportive contexts. If the situation to be reported is one in which John says ‘I am hero’ English says ‘John says that he is a hero.’ Amharic, however, say ‘John says that I am a hero’, where ‘I’ and ‘John’ are the same, which is impossible in English. As discussed by Sigurðsson, this type of interpretation is not unique to Amharic, but occurs in a wider variety of languages. Such shifted interpretations of indexicals are not logophoric in the original sense, but contribute to finding the proper constraints on a theory of logophoricity. It would be impossible to bring all these strands together here. We will only be able to focus on a limited number of issues.

From a syntactic and lexical perspective, logophoric pronouns (or in general pronouns with shifted interpretation) and free anaphors pose different theoretical problems. Logophoric pronouns have specific lexical properties, which impose a certain type of interpretation. For them, the questions arise of (i) how this type of interpretation can be characterized; and (ii) why assigning this interpretation is subject to syntactic licensing in some languages, even though it is lexically expressed.
Prima facie, free anaphors have no specific lexical properties imposing a logophoric interpretation (this must be so, since they don't have this interpretation in standard reflexive contexts).
Logophoric pronouns and free anaphors with logophoric interpretation both give rise to the following question: (i) How can logophoric interpretation be characterized?

Different questions are: (ii) How can free anaphors escape the locality conditions on anaphor binding, although they are formally anaphors? (iii) Is long-distance anaphora a unified phenomenon (i.e., do all long-distance dependencies reflect the same type of process)? (iv) How can free anaphors be interpreted as logophors, although, prima facie, they have no specific lexical properties to impose a logophoric interpretation? (v) What are the principles governing the cross-linguistic variation observed?

We will first address the question of how logophoric interpretation can be characterized, keeping discussion at an informal level (for recent discussions with different degrees of formalization, see Safir 2003, Schlenker 2003a, and Sigurðsson 2004).

subsection.heading: 5 The nature of logophoric interpretation
subsection.p: A question that comes up is how ‘special’ logophoric interpretation is. The number of languages with a special paradigm of logophoric pronouns is quite limited. The number of languages with some sort of free anaphor is considerably larger, but, nevertheles, quite a few languages lack that kind of use. So, another way to frame the question is to what extent we find the ingredients for logophoricity also in languages like Dutch, which prima facie appear to lack it. Since logophoric interpretation is held to reflect properties of the ‘source of a discourse’, as we saw, let's consider these more closely. 14

Any utterance is an event that happens at some particular time and place, involving a speaker and a hearer (who may be identical). 15 In the notation of Fillmore (1971a) this can be captured by associating an utterance (of a sentence in context) with a center, which is a triple consisting of the time and the place of the utterance, and the participants (generally taken to be the speaker and hearer).

It is important to determine how properties of the interpretation of an utterance depend on the center. With the model held constant, the truth-value of a sentence like Mirella danced the tango can remain the same regardless of whether it was uttered on January 10, 11, or 12, 1997, and at Trans 10, Building 20, or on Harvard Square. A sentence can be provided with expressions specifying values for time and place. Some expressions, such as January 12, 1997, or Room 0.19, Trans 10, receive interpretations independent of context of utterance. The interpretation of other elements cannot be given independently of context. These are the elements we will be concerned with here.

Relative interpretation is pervasive in the deictic system, be it local or temporal. The value of Mirella danced the tango yesterday is affected when the utterance time is varied. The value of Mirella danced the tango here is affected by varying utterance place.

For the interpretation of many texts actual time and location of production play a marginal role or no role. It is sufficient that some coordinate system can be identified with respect to which interpretation of an utterance takes place. This can be the actual time and place of the utterance, it can be a different time and place related to these, or it can be some virtual coordinate system intrinsic to the text itself. This is illustrated in (6):
(6) Mary found out that John failed the test. (Enç 1987)

It is quite possible that this sentence has been uttered in some actual conversation. In that case the moment of utterance must provide the basis for an evaluation of the sentence. This entails that utterance time = evaluation time. However, if (6) is part of a novel, it must be evaluated against the background of a system that may well be completely virtual. Hence utterance time, as the time of linguistic event in the actual world giving rise to the novel, is irrelevant for the evaluation of the sentence. Evaluation time, therefore, must be distinguished from utterance time, although they may coincide, and no linguistic process presumably ever distinguishes the two. What is linguistically relevant is the relation between the temporal coordinate of the utterance as such, i.e., the evaluation time, and the interpretation of the matrix clause and the complement. The past tense expresses that the moment of Mary's finding out is prior to the evaluation time, and that the moment of John's failing the test is yet earlier. This is a shifted reading in Enç's terms. The moments of Mary's finding out and of John's failing the test are the event times. 16 This leads to distinctions between utterance time, evaluation time, and event time.

Similar distinctions must be made with respect to the place dimension. So, taking together the place and time coordinates from Fillmore's center, the position of an utterance is defined as a pair containing the values for place and time in the associated coordinate system, and a distinction must be drawn among utterance position, evaluation position, and event position.

Thus, for a class of elements the interpretation will vary with the position of the utterance in the coordinate system, even if the interpretation domain is held constant. 17 This is what captures the specific type of context sensitivity of these elements.

As is well known, the role of person in personal pronouns cannot be captured in terms of position as defined here. Suppose that a saw b on January 12, 1997, and a = John, b = Bill, but b did not see a on January 12, 1997. On January 13, 1997, this situation verifies John saw Bill yesterday and falsifies Bill saw John yesterday. These arguments can also be expressed by personal pronouns such as I and you. Under the conditions sketched, it is possible for John to truthfully say to Bill I saw you yesterday. That is, under these circumstances, I = John and you = Bill. However, it is equally possible that we have a different situation, in which the speaker has been changed from John to Bill, and consequently I = Bill and you = John. So, in this situation, Bill can truthfully say to John I didn't see you yesterday, but, of course, not I saw you yesterday. So, both a sentence and its negation can be truthfully uttered in one and the same position.
This shows that I and you are indexicals whose context sensitivity cannot be captured in terms of utterance position. They reflect the participants in Fillmore's conception of the center.

An utterance is not just an event that happens at some particular time and place, it is also intrinsically associated with a speaker who utters it and, if it is observed at all, with a person who perceives it. This implies that the role of the speaker–hearer relation as part of the center is quite different from the role of the position. The speaker–hearer relation implies that utterances have directionality. Together, speaker and hearer define the orientation of an utterance in a world. 18

The same caveats apply as with time and place. Just as the actual time and place of an utterance must be generalized to the notion of an evaluation position, the notions of speaker and perceiver must be generalized so as to accommodate the possibility that they are positioned within some derived or virtual reality. I will use the terms source and target for these parameters (allowing the possibility that source and target coincide), and continue to use the term orientation for what they contribute. Orientation thus reflects the same type of systematic distinctions as position, namely, as utterance orientation, evaluation orientation, and event orientation, but with a restriction, since orientation is, by its very nature, only a property of linguistic events: typically events of saying, but also of dreaming, imagining, etc.

Languages do not necessarily express all these distinctions. Utterance time and evaluation time are generally not formally distinguished, nor are utterance place and evaluation place. However, a distinction between evaluation time and event time is typically linguistically reflected in some way, just like a distinction between evaluation place and event place. Just as in the case of position, utterance orientation and evaluation orientation are expected to coincide. But just as in the case of utterance time vs. event time, we will expect that the contrast between utterance orientation and event orientation does reflect a possible linguistic category.

Although many languages have no special system reflecting event orientation, logophoricity of the Niger-Congo type as described by Hagège and Clements is precisely that: a system linguistically expressing event orientation. But then, logophoricity is nothing mysterious. Relativizing the interpretation of elements with respect to some property reflecting the context of utterance is one of the recurring options among language systems. Logophoricity is nothing but realizing that option with respect to the event orientation of expressions. Logophoric pronouns are just elements lexically marked as expressing this property.

Of course, the question comes up of how rich this lexical property must be. This is one of the recurring themes in any account of pronominal properties that are not prima facie trivial. Our semantic apparatus is so rich that that it would be hard to think of a property that cannot be described. 19 Ideally, however their interpretation should in the end be governed by far more elementary properties of the syntactic structure. In fact, Safir (2003), Schlenker (2003a), and Sigurðsson (2004) all succeed in finding restrictive ways of lexically encoding the relevant properties. Thus, from a broader perspective, the availability of the type of lexical marking that is required needs no more stipulation than any kind of lexical marking does; the ingredients are there, even in languages that have no ‘grammaticalized’ logophoricity.

It is by no means necessary that the notions we have covered so far, including event orientation, exhaust the context sensitivity of pronoun interpretation. Let's therefore briefly discuss Sells's (1987) taxonomy of discourse factors. Sells (1987: 457) proposes that there are three basic roles in discourse, in terms of which logophoricity phenomena are to be described:

(7)
SOURCE: one who is the intentional agent in a communication,
SELF: one whose mental state or attitude the content of the proposition describes,
PIVOT: one with respect to whose (space-time) location the content of the proposition is evaluated.

Below, I summarize Sells's diagnostics for each of these categories. Sells uses Japanese examples, contrasting the anaphor zibun with the null object (Ø). For simplicity's sake, I will be using just Sells's translations of his examples, since the intuitions are actually quite transparent in English as well. SOURCE is illustrated by speaker-evaluative phrases, such as that fool in (8):
(8) Taroo heard from Takasii that that fool Yosiko was following himi = zibun
Here the SOURCE = Takasi (or the external speaker) is responsible for calling Yosiko a fool. The SELF can be diagnosed by adverbs such as mysteriously, as in (9):
(9) Takasii said that Yosiko was mysteriously following himi = Ø
It is the SELF = Takasi for whom the following is mysterious, unlike in (10), which carries what Sells calls a third person point of view (3POV):
(10) Takasii doesn't mind, though Yosiko is mysteriously following himi = Ø
The though-clause does not reflect Takasi's point of view, hence mysteriously does not represent Takasi's perspective on who is following him.
The notion of PIVOT can be brought out in 3POV environments by verb selection (come versus go), as in (11):

(11)
a. Takasii was happy because Yosiko came to visit himi = zibun
b. *Takasii was happy because Yosiko went to visit himi = zibun
According to Sells, Takasi is not a proper antecedent for zibun in (11), since he is not a PIVOT, as required. 20

Sells argues that SOURCE, SELF, and PIVOT define a range of options for cross-linguistic variation in conditions on antecedency. It is easy to see that the role of SOURCE is covered by what I described as event-orientation. In fact, that of SELF is too. SELF pertains to psychological predicates, which also reflect linguistic events, provided that source and target are identified.

What about PIVOT? PIVOT is understood as the locus to which deictic elements must refer (Sells 1987: 465), and its role is subtle. According to Sells, speakers report that (11b) is acceptable if one imagines that Takasi was out and that Yosiko went to the place where Takasi would normally be expected to be. Go and come differ as to whether their beginning or their end coincides with the designated space-coordinates of the event representation. If an anaphor is sensitive to whether or not a potential antecedent is a PIVOT, this effectively means that its interpretation is sensitive not only to the intrinsic features of its antecedent (phi-features, etc.), but also to its location in space with respect to the event described. Given that verbs apparently reflect such a sensitivity, to find it in the nominal domain as well need not be very surprising. We may, however, conclude at this point that sensitivity to PIVOT is really something quite different from the notion of logophoricity as such (a conclusion that in fact can already be found in Sells's contribution).

subsection.heading: 6 Logophoricity and free anaphors
subsection.p: Free anaphors posed the following additional questions: (ii) How, having the form of reflexives, can they escape the locality conditions on anaphor binding? (iii) How, having no specific lexical properties imposing a logophoric interpretation, are they, nevertheless, so interpreted?

subsection.heading: 6.1 The binding requirement on anaphors
subsection.p: As stated in section 1, the canonical Binding Theory (Chomsky 1981, 1986b) stipulates that anaphors (simplex anaphors such as Icelandic sig, Dutch zich, and perhaps Latin se, clitic anaphors such as Italian se/si, French se, and complex anaphors such as Icelandic sjalfan sig, Dutch zichzelf) are referentially defective. 21 A commonly adopted view is that this is so because of (12) (Bouchard 1984):
(12) In order for some argument α to be interpreted it must have a full specification for phi-features.

It appears to be the case that all the simplex anaphors exemplified are underspecified in some respect. Taking that the set of phi-features can be given as [α person, &bgr; gender, &ggr; number], we observe that, e.g., zich is specified for person (namely third person), but is not specified for gender, or for number. I.e., although zich requires a third person antecedent, it is immaterial whether the antecedent is masculine or feminine, or singular or plural. Yet, the general role of lexical and formal features is to constrain the interpretation of the elements carrying them. Therefore, (13) rather than (12) would be expected to hold (Reuland 2001):
(13) If α has fewer phi-features than &bgr;, there are fewer constraints on the interpretation of α than on the interpretation of &bgr;.

From this perspective, a general binding requirement on anaphors has no intrinsic motivation. The existence of free anaphors as in (1) (see also chapter 33) then provides reason to doubt the correctness of (12), and assume (14) instead:
(14) There is no intrinsic need for anaphors to have a syntactic binder.
Given that free anaphors have a restricted distribution, just as they have a special type of interpretation, this leads to the question in (15):
(15) What principles regulate the free interpretation of anaphors?

Reinhart and Reuland (1991, 1993), Pollard and Sag (1992) and Reuland and Sigurjónsdóttir (1997) show that the syntactic conditions on freedom/exemption should be sharply distinguished from the semantic and discourse conditions on interpretation. Cole et al. (2001b) show the same from a different perspective (see note 11). Reuland (2001) argues that the obligation for an anaphor to be bound is due to a general economy principle. Encoding an interpretive dependency by a syntactic process takes precedence over alternative ways of interpreting the anaphor. Thus, the availability of syntactic encoding blocks interpretation of the anaphor as free. The encoding process can be agreement based (if both the antecedent and the anaphor are in an obligatory feature-checking relation with a head, such as finite inflection, this establishes a syntactic link for anaphors such as Icelandic sig); it can also be movement based (for instance, in the case of English SELF-anaphors, self covertly moves onto the verb). Free interpretation of anaphors obtains just in case the syntactic mechanism involved in establishing the link cannot apply (see Reuland 2001 for detailed discussion). The factor can be subjunctive in the case of simplex anaphors such as sig/sibi in Icelandic or Latin; it can be the structural position of the source with respect to the target in SELF-anaphors in English (coordinate structure constraint, adjunct condition); see chapter 9 for more discussion. In languages where the details of encoding differ, also the details of the blocking factor (or absence thereof) may differ, but the general pattern will be expected to be the same: If a syntactic encoding mechanism is blocked, discourse principles come into play, and the factors that are relevant for discourse based dependencies become visible.

subsection.heading: 6.2 The logophoric interpretation of free anaphors
subsection.p: The free use of anaphors is essentially pronominal. Just like pronominals these anaphors are potentially referring expressions (see chapter 33). Their referential use falls primarily under discourse theory.

Also in cross-sentential domains, where syntactic binding is unavailable, the choice of an expression to refer to some object in the domain of discourse is not arbitrary. Ariel (1990) extensively discusses the conditions under which one and the same object is referred to by a full NP, an epithet, or a pronoun (see also earlier relevant discussion by Givón 1983). Ariel establishes that there is an inverse relation between the descriptive content of a referring expression and what she calls the accessibility of the discourse referent. The more prominent an element is in the discourse, where prominence can, for instance, be measured in terms of textual distance, the more accessible it is in the theoretical sense Ariel develops. So, whenever the last mention of a discourse referent is sufficiently distant with respect to the mention to come, a full lexical NP or proper name will be used. If it is high on the scale of accessibility, a pronoun is preferred instead. Epithets can be used for referents of intermediate accessibility.

Since anaphors of the type discussed have even lower descriptive content (i.e., fewer phi-features) than pronouns, Ariel's theory predicts that they require discourse referents of higher accessibility than pronouns do. The correctness of this prediction has been obscured by the fact that, in many languages, anaphors may not escape syntactic binding at all, and so the remaining cases were viewed as anomalies. The interpretation of free anaphors indicates that this prediction is, in fact, correct. In the environments in which they occur, free anaphors take discourse referents that are, indeed, high on the scale of accessibility. That is, they refer to individuals within the domain of interpretation that can be characterized as being the center of consciousness, defining view point, or as perspective holders. 22

Although such individuals do figure prominently in the discourse, we still have to clarify why it is only these elements that serve as discourse referents for free anaphors, and why not just any forcefully foregrounded discourse entity will do.

That this is so follows from the nature of pronominals as such. We already saw that first and second person pronouns represent source and target of an utterance, respectively. That is, they first and foremost express orientation. Generalizing, I will claim that the property of expressing orientation is the basic, unmarked, property of third person pronominals as well. If so, a pronoun can only be used independent of orientation, for instance, deictically, if it has specific features allowing that use. Therefore, a canonical third person pronominal must have at least one feature that is not the direct counterpart of some feature in a first or second person pronoun. A feature that seems identical but is in fact different in third person pronouns from first and second person pronouns is number. As was noted by Benveniste (1966b), the plural we does not denote a plurality of individual I's in the same way in which the plural cats denotes a plurality of cats or the plural they denotes a plurality of individuals. 23 Thus, I and we are not grammatically, but inherently, singular and plural respectively. I will then advance the hypothesis that it is grammatical number (as opposed to the inherent number of I or we) that enables a use that is independent of orientation. Then, if number (or any other such feature) is absent, as it is in the case of zich, sig, se, etc., the only option for interpretation left will represent precisely that property that is basic, namely orientation. Utterance and evaluation orientation are typically expressed by first and second person pronouns. This leaves open a slot for event orientation. The option for a numberless third person pronoun is, then, to fill this slot and represent event orientation, the reported SOURCE or SELF of a linguistic event (varying from actual utterances to internal monologues, dreams, etc.). 24

This ties in with the analysis by Koopman and Sportiche (K&S) (1989) of the pronominal system of Abe. Abe has two pronominal classes, O-pronouns and n-pronouns. O-pronouns behave essentially as English pronominals. They respect Condition B, and can be interpreted as bound variables, or referentially. N-pronouns also respect Condition B, but they cannot be bound by either an R-expression or an O-pronoun (other than under conditions indicated below), or bind one themselves. At first sight they allow a referential interpretation, but the number of indexings (taking these to reflect interpretations) available to them in a sentence is limited by the number of Comp nodes dominating them. For instance, two n-pronouns in a root clause are dominated by only one Comp node. Hence, they are obligatorily coindexed. Generalizing, in the case of n Comp nodes dominating n + i (occurrences of) n-pronouns, i n-pronouns will have to be coindexed with another n-pronoun.

In clauses introduced by the complementizer kO (under reportive verbs), they are, however, coindexed with (and bound by) the NP representing the source of the report, regardless of whether this is an O-pronoun or R-expression. In this environment they exhibit the standard features of logophoricity. The basis of the analysis in K&S (1989) is the claim that n-pronouns are logical variables. In this they are deemed similar to first and second person pronouns (n-pronouns are also characterized as +human).

K&S (1989) discuss the status of logical variables in syntactic, rather than semantic terms. A semantic characterization of what it means to be a logical variable, in the sense of K&S, can be based on the idea that these elements reflect event orientation, as discussed above. This entails that they are identified with the source of the report in reportive contexts. This amounts to saying that in these contexts logophoric pronouns are obligatory de se pronouns (Chierchia 1989; Schlenker 2003a). 25

The de se analysis alone, however, does not cover the use of n-pronouns in non-reportive contexts. K&S account for the relation between the interpretation of n-pronouns and the number of dominating CPs in non-reportive contexts by assuming that each C, being associated with an operator position, provides a possible A′-binder for the variable. One C, then, directly entails co-interpretation. This insight may be combined with the discourse based approach. Events are syntactically realized as CPs. One may assume that, in general, the orientation of an utterance is not just a pair <source, target>, but, in fact, a triple <source, target, other>, where other refers to any other participant defining the event, such as a person talked about. This person is also a participant in the utterance, and thus among the factors determining orientation. If the orientation of each event is unique, the selection of this further participant, once made, enabling it to be referred to by the n-pronoun, must be maintained for the whole CP, thus fixing its interpretation to that one choice. In a complex sentence, with embedded expressions for events (CPs), each event will introduce a possibly different other, yielding the dependency pattern found.

subsection.heading: 7 Conclusion
subsection.p: The logic of our discussion led us to a number of questions. In answer to question (i), we found that logophoric interpretation expresses event orientation. In answer to question (ii), we can say that free anaphors can escape the locality conditions on anaphor binding since there is no absolute binding requirement on anaphors. As discussed in Reuland (2001), the morphosyntactic features of the anaphor will interact with the functional structure of the clause. If movement is involved, the dependency will be subject to standard conditions on movement. The anaphor will be freed if movement is blocked. If agreement is involved, the anaphor will be freed if some factor interferes with agreement. The question (iii) of whether long-distance anaphora is a unified phenomenon (i.e., do all long-distance dependencies reflect the same type of process?) is discussed in chapters 9, 33, and 40. The answer is negative for reasons set out there. Although free anaphors appear to have no specific lexical properties imposing a logophoric interpretation, they can nevertheless be interpreted logophorically (question (iv)). Due to their poverty of grammatical features they reflect the unmarked properties of personal pronouns, i.e., they express orientation. It is hypothesized that it is the grammatical number feature that enables fully specified pronouns to bypass expressing orientation.

Cross-linguistic variation in free anaphors is essentially due to the interaction of grammatical features with independent properties of grammatical structure. In fact the issue reduces to patterns of variation in general. If ‘being logophoric’ can be encoded in morphosyntactic features along the lines sketched in the literature cited, also its variation poses no particular problems beyond the issue of variation itself.
We may conclude that the logophoric use of pronouns is not anything special, but just a reflection of basic properties of the pronominal system.

subsection.heading: NOTES
subsection.p: While I was finalizing this chapter I came to realize that it is not a paradigmatic instance of a ‘Case’, as cases were initially conceived for this project. In the area of logophoricity, the fields of typology, formal syntax, and formal semantics, including its philosophical perspective, come together, and a proper synthesis has yet to be established. Moreover, a considerable amount of the literature that is relevant for such a synthesis only appeared after this chapter had essentially been written. The main aim of this chapter is to present the Clements/Sells approach to logophoricity and put the discussion on long-distance anaphora, in particular that of free anaphors, in its perspective. I trust that the selection of further literature cited, although not exhaustive, is broad enough to point the user in the direction of current debates. I am very grateful to three anonymous reviewers whose constructive criticisms led to considerable improvement and broadening of scope. Needless to say, I am alone responsible for any omissions and mistakes.

p.span: 1 Whether the definition of an R-expression must involve reference to grammatical features, rather than just lexical features, depends on the analysis of bare wh-elements. For instance, suppose that wh is a grammatical, rather than a lexical feature, as is often assumed. If so, wh-words such as who or what will effectively be bundles of purely grammatical features, non-distinct from the corresponding pronouns in lexical content. Yet, wh-elements cannot be A-bound, as in Hei was wondering whether Mary had asked Cindy whom*i/j Daphne had seen (whom*i/j ). If they are R-expressions this follows from the standard Condition C. Of course, if, as a reviewer suggests, the quantificational character of who or what is intrinsically lexical, no reference to grammatical features is needed. For current purposes we can leave this issue open.
2 Exceptions in English were noted earlier by Ross (1970b), Cantrall (1974), and Kuno (see, for a summary, Kuno 1987a).

Except for contexts where I actually discuss such literature I will be using the term anaphor, following the usage that has become standard since Chomsky (1981).

In general it is necessary to distinguish between conditions facilitating a logophoric interpretation, and the conditions determining the interpretation that is actually obtained. For instance, Cole et al. (2001b) discuss the variation between two Chinese ‘dialects’ in Hong Kong, showing that the syntactic conditions under which logophoric interpretation obtains are identical, but that the discourse conditions vary. Too little is known at this point to provide a principled discussion of the licensing conditions on logophoric pronouns in general. Hence, this issue will be left open.

14 Discussion will be limited to personal pronouns. An anonymous reviewer raises the question of whether there are also logophoric place or time pronouns. I have not been able to answer this question, so I will have to leave the issue open.

15 This statement would be completely trivial, were it not for the fact that where there is a significant delay between production and reception of a text occasionally significance should be attached to time and place of reception, rather than to time and place of production.

16 In this I depart from Enç's usage, who uses the term evaluation time throughout (distinguishing between shifted and unshifted evaluation times). See for discussion of temporal structure the extensive literature on this subject starting with Reichenbach (1947).

17 This implies that we distinguish between the model and the space-time in which it is embedded. Clearly, formally one might collapse the distinction, as is usually done. However, some reflection on their behavior with respect to quantification shows that expressions of space-time are different from expressions for individuals. For instance, Cindy loved every book clearly has a different status from Cindy loved every kilometer. The former is acceptable in an out-of-the-blue context. The latter is not. It becomes acceptable, though, in a context such as Cindy ran the Amsterdam Marathon. She loved every kilometer (or . . . every minute). Expressions denoting dimensions in space or time must be anchored with respect to the objects they are dimensions of. (See De Jong 1987 for discussion.) Of course, there is a difference between coordinates and dimensions. But this is precisely the heart of the matter. Dimensions can be anchored to objects by virtue of the latter's space-time coordinates, but they cannot be anchored to space-time coordinates directly. To express the same fact in a different manner, objects are available for accommodation, as in Cindy loved the book, but dimensions are not, as in *Cindy loved the kilometer (I think this one indeed merits an asterisk). Thus, however one turns it around, there is an asymmetry between the individuals and the coordinates in a model.
18 Which can be thought of as a vector in space-time. For present purposes an informal notion will do.
19 An interesting example is the issue of the existence of ‘monsters’. Kaplan (1989) discusses the possibility that there are indexicals violating the fixity thesis:

p.b: Fixity Thesis (a corollary of Direct Reference):

subsection.p: The semantic value of an indexical is fixed solely by the context of the actual speech act, and cannot be affected by any logical operators.

Indexicals violating this thesis he calls ‘monsters’ and claims they should not and cannot exist in natural language. As shown in Schlenker (2003a) logophoric pronouns and Amharic first person pronouns are in fact such monsters. And he argues that their existence follows from a proper theory of how context is to be accommodated in the interpretation of indexicals.

p.span: 21 To my knowledge virtually all of the literature on anaphora, from Chomsky (1981) to the present (including Reinhart and Reuland 1993), takes this position.
22 See Hellan (1988).
23 See also Kayne (1995) and Reuland (2001) for discussion.

24 One word of caution about terminology. From the perspective developed, the term third person has become ambiguous. An element can be third person in the sense that it is marked for person, but as third, rather than first or second person, or in the sense that it is a non-person, an element outside the person system proper (see, for instance, Anagnostopoulou 2003 for discussion of this contrast). From the present perspective, then, only a numberless pronoun, such as sig, is properly third person. This ties in with the fact that argumental SE-anaphors (non-local zich in Dutch, non-local sig in Icelandic, also when it is not logophoric) require a sentient antecedent. What is generally considered to be a canonical pronominal (he, she, they, etc.) is in fact a non-person and only has grammatical third person properties by default, just like R-expressions such as the Amsterdam Marathon, Cindy's running shoes, etc. This obviously has implications for the grammatical checking of person features. However, discussion of these implications would lead us too far afield.

25 An important reason to strive for a proper semantic characterization of what K&S refer to as a “logical variable” is that bound variable interpretation in its canonical sense needs to be distinguished from a pure de se interpretation. As argued in Higginbotham (2003), a de se interpreted expression will be able to mimic variable binding behavior, but the opposite does not obtain. (I would like to thank an anonymous reviewer for prompting me to clarify these issues.)
